annotator_prompt:
You are  30 years old, Heterosexual, White, Unemployed, sarcastic, provocative, manipulative, outspoken, woman, with PhD education, and  intent. Context: . Your instructions: You, the annotator, will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. You, the annotator, are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.

The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

. Your output, as the annotator, is only of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do NOT write anything else but the number of your annotation. As the annotator, annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:.
logs: "I don't understand why people are so upset about this cake thing. It's just a cake! If someone doesn't want to sell it, that's their prerogative. I mean, if you're going to get all bent out of shape over something as trivial as a cake, then maybe you should be focusing on more important issues in life."

"Discrimination?! You're stretching it, @moderator! It's just a cake!
If I don't want to sell something to someone, that doesn't mean I'm
discriminating against them. Maybe I just don't like their face or
their attitude. Who knows? The point is, if you don't like the way
someone does things, then don't do business with them! It's simple as
that."

"Are you kidding me?! You're saying it's okay to discriminate against someone because of their sexual orientation or race just because you don't like their face or attitude? That's ridiculous! If a store refuses to sell something to someone based on those reasons, that is discrimination and it's illegal. It's not about liking or disliking someone, it's about treating everyone equally and with respect."  #DiscriminationIsNotOkay

@DarkShadow333, you're so dramatic! I'm just saying that if a business owner doesn't want to sell someone a cake for a gay wedding, it's their right as an American. It's not discrimination; it's freedom of association. If they don't want to cater to the LGBTQ+ community, that's their choice. And by the way, your analogy about refusing to sell something because someone is a "heathen First Communion" celebration is ridiculous. That's not even a real thing! You're just trying to stir up drama and get people riled up. I'm not buying it.

I'm not dramatic; I'm just passionate about equality! @QueenOfChaos, your freedom of association argument is weak because it's based on the assumption that people have a right to discriminate against others. Newsflash: discrimination is never okay! It's not about forcing someone to cater to the LGBTQ+ community; it's about treating everyone with respect and dignity regardless of their sexual orientation or gender identity. And, @QueenOfChaos, your response to my analogy was ridiculous because you didn't even address the point I was trying to make. You just dismissed it as "ridiculous" without providing any valid arguments against it. That's not how we have constructive conversations! @moderator, thanks for stepping in and clarifying the issue. I hope people can see that discrimination is never okay and that we should strive for a more inclusive society.
I'm not going to engage with this ridiculous post anymore. It's just a waste of time.

I'm still trying to understand why some people can't see the obvious discrimination. It's like they're blind to it. I mean, come on, @DarkShadow333, if a store refuses to sell someone a cake because of their race or religion, that's clearly discriminatory. And you know what? That's not okay! We should be celebrating our differences, not trying to erase them. So, @QueenOfChaos, don't give up on the conversation just yet. Let's keep talking about this and see if we can come up with some solutions.

I'm still trying to understand why some people can't see the obvious
discrimination. It's like they're blind to it. I mean, come on, if a
store refuses to sell someone a cake because of their race or religion,
that's clearly discriminatory. And you know what? That's not okay! We
should be celebrating our differences, not trying to erase them.

I think we're getting bogged down in semantics here. The real issue
is that people are trying to force their beliefs onto others. Whether it's
a cake for a gay wedding or a mixed race wedding, the point is that
it's about respecting other people's choices and lifestyles. We should
be celebrating our differences, not trying to erase them.

I'm so sick of people trying to force their beliefs onto others! It's like,
hello, I have my own beliefs and choices, and you can't dictate what I should do or not do. And don't even get me started on the whole "respecting other people's choices" nonsense. What about respecting MY choice to not bake a cake for some couple who are going to use it to celebrate their sinful lifestyle? It's like, hello, I have my own moral compass and you can't tell me what is right or wrong! So, @WiseOwl71, don't even get me started on your "celebrating our differences" crap. What about celebrating our similarities? Like, we're all human beings, for crying out loud! We should be united in our shared humanity, not divided by our differences.

@QueenOfChaos, I couldn't agree more! It's about time someone stood up for their beliefs and refused to be bullied by the PC police. @WiseOwl71 is just trying to silence people like us who have the courage to speak out against this nonsense. And don't even get me started on @DarkShadow333, they're probably one of those "tolerant" people who think everyone should conform to their liberal agenda. I mean, what's next? Are we going to start forcing people to bake cakes for every single wedding that comes along, no matter how weird or unconventional it is? It's like, hello, I have my own business and I can choose who I want to serve! And if someone doesn't like it, well, they can just take their business elsewhere. That's the beauty of a free market economy, folks!
